content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Search for a flight on December 19 and return on December 26 from Tel Aviv to Venice and Select First Class.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to change seating class from Economy to First Class. First open the seating class combobox.
Action: Click 755
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: In the seating class list, need to select "First" option.
Action: Click 808
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to change origin; open “Where from?” combobox.
Action: Click 11
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to replace current origin with “Tel Aviv”.
Action: Type 12; Tel Aviv
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to set destination. Open “Where to?” combobox.
Action: Click 13
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Input destination “Venice”.
Action: Type 14; Venice
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to open date picker to set departure December 19.
Action: Click 15
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Try manually entering the departure date; the Departure textbox (17) is focused.  
Action: Type 17; Dec 19, 2024
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to input the return date in the Return textbox (element 18).
Action: Type 18; Dec 26, 2024
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Departure and return dates have been entered; confirm date picker with “Done”.
Action: Click 1132
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: All parameters are set (Tel Aviv → Venice, Dec 19 – Dec 26, First Class). Run the search to view available flights.
Action: Click 1151
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The date‑picker dialog is still open; click “Done” to confirm the selected Dec 19 – Dec 26 dates and close the dialog.
Action: Click 1132
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Dates are confirmed; run the search for the specified Tel‑Aviv → Venice first‑class round‑trip.
Action: Click 1151
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The date‑picker dialog is still open; use the “Done” button to close it and apply the chosen dates.
Action: Click 1132
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: All parameters are set (Tel Aviv → Venice, Dec 19–Dec 26, First Class). Run the search to load flight results.  
Action: Click 1151
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate December 2024 in the date‑picker; scroll the calendar upward to earlier months.
Action: Scroll 2227; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to continue moving the calendar to earlier months so we can reach December 2024; keep scrolling the date grid upward.  
Action: Scroll 2227; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Must reach December 2024; continue scrolling calendar upward (earlier months).  
Action: Scroll 2227; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Still at May 2025; need to scroll calendar further up to reach 2024 months.
Action: Scroll 2227; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: We’re still in May 2025. Continue scrolling the calendar grid upward to reach December 2024.
Action: Scroll 2227; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Instead of scrolling, I can directly overwrite the Departure textbox (still focused) with the desired date “Dec 19, 2024”; this should jump the calendar to December 2024.
Action: Type 17; Dec 19, 2024
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar still displays May 2025. I must move further back to reach December 2024, so I’ll scroll the calendar grid upward again.
Action: Scroll 2227; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Enter the return date in the Return textbox so that both dates are set to the required December 19–26, 2024 range.  
Action: Type 18; Dec 26, 2024
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure date is incorrect (currently May 2 2025). I need to reach December 2024 in the calendar to pick Dec 19, so I should keep scrolling the calendar grid upward toward earlier months.  
Action: Scroll 2227; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I still need to navigate to earlier months (toward December 2024). I will try scrolling the calendar grid in the opposite direction to check if earlier months appear.
Action: Scroll 2227; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The only other navigation control besides “Next” is the unnamed image element (1028) that likely serves as the “Previous month” arrow. Clicking it should move the calendar to earlier months so I can reach December 2024.
Action: Click 1028

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Scrolling the calendar grid downward should move to earlier months (April 2025, March 2025, …) so that we can get to December 2024.
Action: Scroll 2227; down
The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.

Thought: The calendar dialog itself (1012) may be scrollable; moving its viewport upward should reveal the navigation controls (back arrow) positioned above the currently visible months, letting us reach December 2024.
Action: Scroll 1012; up
The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.

Thought: The calendar uses navigation arrows; the button just before “Next month” is the “Previous month” arrow. I’ll click the element right before the “Next” button to move back toward December 2024.
Action: Click 1027
The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.

Thought: Year header element might let choosing year to quickly reach 2024. Click it.
Action: Click 1017
